The **doctrine of lapse** was an [annexation](/wiki/Annexation "Annexation")
policy applied by the [British East India
Company](/wiki/British_East_India_Company "British East India Company") in
[India](/wiki/India "India") before 1858. According to the doctrine, any
[princely state](/wiki/Principality "Principality") or territory under the
direct influence (paramountacy) of the [British East India
Company](/wiki/British_East_India_Company "British East India Company") (the
dominant [imperial](/wiki/Imperialism "Imperialism") power in the
[subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent")), as a [vassal
state](/wiki/Vassal_state "Vassal state") under the British subsidiary system,
would automatically be annexed if the ruler was either "manifestly incompetent
or died without a male heir".[1] The latter supplanted the long-established
right of an Indian sovereign without an heir to choose a successor.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In
addition, the British decided whether potential rulers were competent enough.
The doctrine and its application were widely regarded by many Indians as
illegitimate.

The policy is most commonly associated with [Lord
Dalhousie](/wiki/James_Andrew_Broun-Ramsay,_1st_Marquess_of_Dalhousie "James
Andrew Broun-Ramsay, 1st Marquess of Dalhousie"), who was the [Governor
General](/wiki/Governor_General "Governor General") for the [East India
Company](/wiki/East_India_Company "East India Company") in [India](/wiki/India
"India") between 1848 and 1856. However, it was articulated by the Court of
Directors of the East India Company as early as 1834 and several smaller
states were already annexed under this doctrine before Dalhousie took over the
post of Governor-General. Dalhousie used the policy most vigorously and
extensively, though, so it is generally associated with him.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Doctrine_of_lapse&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

At the time of its adoption, the British East India Company had imperial
administrative jurisdiction over wide regions of the subcontinent. The company
took over the princely states of
[Satara](/w/index.php?title=Satara_State&action=edit&redlink=1 "Satara State
\(page does not exist\)") (1848), [Jaitpur](/wiki/Jaitpur_State "Jaitpur
State") and [Sambalpur](/wiki/Sambalpur_State "Sambalpur State") (1849),
[Nagpur](/wiki/Nagpur_State "Nagpur State") and [Jhansi](/wiki/Jhansi_State
"Jhansi State") (1854), [Tanjore](/wiki/Thanjavur_Maratha_kingdom "Thanjavur
Maratha kingdom") and [Arcot](/wiki/Nawab_of_the_Carnatic "Nawab of the
Carnatic") (1855) and [Udaipur
(Chhattisgarh)](/wiki/Udaipur_State,_Chhattisgarh "Udaipur State,
Chhattisgarh") under the terms of the doctrine of lapse.
[Oudh](/wiki/Oudh_State "Oudh State") (1856) is widely believed to have been
annexed under the Doctrine of Lapse. However it was annexed by Lord Dalhousie
under the pretext of mis-governance. Mostly claiming that the ruler was not
ruling properly, the Company added about four million pounds sterling to its
annual revenue by virtue of this doctrine.[2] Udaipur State, however, would
have local rule reinstated by the British in 1860.[3]

With the increasing power of the East India Company, discontent simmered among
many sections of Indian society and the largely indigenous armed forces; these
rallied behind the deposed dynasties during the [Indian Rebellion of
1857](/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857 "Indian Rebellion of 1857"), also known
as the Sepoy Mutiny. Following the rebellion, in 1858, the new British
[Viceroy](/wiki/Viceroy "Viceroy") of India, whose rule replaced that of the
British East India Company, renounced the doctrine.[4]

The princely state of
[Kittur](/w/index.php?title=Kittur_State&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kittur State
\(page does not exist\)") was taken over by the East India Company in 1824 by
imposing a 'doctrine of lapse'. So it is debatable whether it was devised by
Lord Dalhousie in 1848, though he arguably made it official by documenting it.
Dalhousie's annexations and the doctrine of lapse had caused suspicion and
uneasiness among most ruling princes in India.

## Doctrine of lapse before
Dalhousie[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Doctrine_of_lapse&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Doctrine of lapse before Dalhousie")]

Dalhousie applied the doctrine of lapse vigorously for annexing Indian
princely states, but the policy was not solely of his invention. The [Court of
Directors](/wiki/List_of_East_India_Company_directors "List of East India
Company directors") of the East India Company had articulated this early in
1834.[5] As per this policy, the Company annexed [Mandvi](/wiki/Mandvi
"Mandvi") in 1839,
[Kolaba](/w/index.php?title=Kolaba_State&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kolaba State
\(page does not exist\)") and [Jalaun](/wiki/Jalaun_State "Jalaun State") in
1840 and [Surat](/wiki/Surat "Surat") in 1842.
